It's changing business models, how you deliver workers to where the jobs are, virtually how you build the cities of the future. And so it is a key part of our overall strategy. You'll see us move in video in many areas. And don't underestimate our view of how important Medianet is to the fabric of being able, any device to any content, in a format, and then being able to not only search off of it, but push it to its communities of interest.
Congratulations, thank you.
One more question, operator, please.
Your last question comes from Simon Leopold with Morgan Keegan.
Great, thank you. Glad I can sneak in last again. I appreciate it.
Simon, they're writing the names down, and I'm reading them sideways. As Laura – as your question come in who's the next one is, so I knew you were there about 10 seconds before you did. Go ahead.

Great. Well thank you. I'm glad for the opportunity. I wanted to drill down on the topic of the U.S. Government. You made a reference a little bit earlier, John, about federal trends. And what I'm looking for is really big picture. You know, what's the trend going on federal in the current quarter? It sounds like a number of companies experienced better federal trends, and if you could extrapolate to how you see overall stimulus programs affecting your business, because clearly it's not just broadband stimulus for you, but multiple programs. So near term, what was federal? And then take that out to the future with stimulus. Thank you.

Sure. Federal did see a very good quarter year-over-year, Rob, I'm going to ask you to expand on that in a little bit, in a moment. And talk about it in a fair amount of detail. But federal from Q1 to Q2 is always down, even in very strong year-over-year growth periods in excess of 50%. So we do see the federal stimulus packages having an effect both in the U.S. but cannily around the world. And you saw public sector in many areas picking up in terms of direction.

In terms of federal programs, we are seeing them begin to drive some very creative areas. And that relates to healthcare, it relates to broadband build outs, et cetera, which play right into our sweet spots which, Rob, you could expand on a little bit as well. We are encouraged by what we're seeing from people out of the administration like Valerie Jarrett listening to business on what are the key issues on tax policies outside the U.S. which could have a very challenging effect on job creation in the U.S. if done wrong. And with Julius Genachowski as an example of the FCC really listening to all sides and starting on the issue of net neutrality kind of in the middle of the page, which can have a lot of impact on many service providers and many high-tech companies.

So I think you see a group that is listening and in the areas that relate to high tech, regardless of political party in terms of its direction. To come specifically to federal, Rob, maybe you'll comment both on what you're seeing but also it was really your idea on how to position our focus on federal both in this country and around the world, if you could expand on that a little bit.

Sure, John. And it was actually about a year ago we started to shift some of our sales coverage to public sector teams around the world. I think that's turned out to be a good investment. You mentioned that public sector grew around the world and was our strongest vertical. Specifically in the United States, we have been tracking the linkage of stimulus funds to key verticals. And I'll tell you where we do see the pipeline building. We're clearly seeing the pipeline building in education, especially in advanced education. We have a number of projects that are being driven as wireless and physical security projects are funded for infrastructure upgrades. We expect in the next few quarters we're going to see some of those broadband projects come to bear and we are all seeing investments being made into the healthcare space that we think will emerge in calendar '10 that may be picked up in the private sector as spending gets placed in different ways, but it will be subject to funding. We're encouraged, John, as well by the residents we're getting around our Smart+Connected Communities messaging.
That's been exciting.

Safety and security, public transportation system, smart and connected buildings especially for government are very relevant today, and we are seeing education and healthcare I think as our two key verticals. So we're in the right spot. This is a global trend. And I think in the federal we're expecting to continue to see what's been positive momentum.
Laura, I think that was the last of our questions.
Thank you, Simon.

One question I didn't get that I was expecting a little bit. And Padma, I can give you the one that really I think is most fascinating. A lot of people really don't understand how clouds are going to evolve. And how they go through phases and position really what was the not just movement to be in private cloud not be as the service that we announced at EMC and VMware and Cisco and with other partners, service provider and system integrators and channel partners. But walk us through the steps as you see that if I were a shareholder, what should I be watching on as cloud emerges? And since you were the one that I asked to set this direction for us over a year ago and then turned it very smoothly, for you and Tony working together in the implementation. Share me a little bit where we are.

Sure, John. I think we strongly believe that cloud is a key in terms of the architectural shift that will impact IT over the next I would say it'll unroll over the next two to five years or so. But I think the key difference, and I think the key point that most people miss is that cloud will have both elements, on-premise and off-premise. And I think we internal clouds or external clouds or private clouds or public clouds. And I think the important factor around our strategy is how do we help enterprises and service providers deal with the fact that we will now have applications and services that will be consumed, partly from on-premise and partly off-premise. And the network obviously plays a key role in making all of this happen.

So the partnership we announced with VMware and EMC is to address the notion of building private clouds using certain blocks that we call Vblock in our announcement where the data center plays a key central role in the architecture. Moving beyond that, we are working on elements that we call cloud networking, where the network actually provides network services in an abstraction layer. We are already engaged in proof of concept and trials with multiple service providers, both large as well as emerging service providers across the world. And we hope to see much traction in the future.

You know, the exciting part is just using service suppliers as an example, our view and their view is the same. You want intelligence in the network. So we naturally align in ways that candidly some of our large peers do not. We don't compete with the service providers. We have the exact same goal on it.
Absolutely.
So, Laura, with that, I'm going to give it back to you. And congratulations. We didn't fumble the ball too many....
No, not too badly.
... times under your leadership. And Blair's grinning. She enjoyed watching that. So why don't you finish it up for us.

Great, John, thank you. I would like to remind our audience that Cisco's Annual Financial Conference will occur on Tuesday, December 8, and will be available to investors via real time video webcast. Our next quarterly conference call, which will reflect our second quarter fiscal year 2010 results, will be on Wednesday, February 3, 2010, at 1:30 p.m. Pacific Time, 4:30 p.m. eastern time. Downloadable Q1 fiscal year '10 financial statements will be available following today's call, including revenue segments by product and geography, income statements, full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information. Balance sheet and cash flow statements can also be found on our website on the IR section. Click on the financial section of the website to access the webcast slides and these documents.

Again, I would like to remind you that in light of Regulation FD, Cisco plans to retain its long-standing policy to not comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done so through an explicit public disclosure. Please call the investor relations team with any follow-up questions from this call. Thank you for your participation and your continued support of our company. This concludes our call.

Thank you for participating on today's conference call. If you would like to listen to the call in its entirety, you may call 866-357-4205. For participants dialing from outside the U.S., please dial 203-369-0122. This concludes today's call. You may disconnect at this time.
